p.s: In his comment, John Worne uses a personal kind of language which will be analizedanalyzed in the following.
The author starts with an epipherepiphora can't, won't, don't (l. 1) which summarizes what he thinks is the British view on foreign languagelanguages.
Besides the obvious effect of this being easyeasily memorizable, those three words actually summarize the problem the UK has from WornesWorne's point of view.
This is a harsh treatment but by using inclusive language, like one can see in the often used word our (i.e. l. 1, 7, or 25,...), he makes this ana less insulting statement.
In combination with ana slightly ironic choisechoice of words, like Perfectly intelligent people (l. 18), the inclusive language makes him seem more sympathetic.
By including counter argumentation (cf. ll. 18-23), even while using ironic language and negating them in short comments, Worne seems to be involved in this topic and mal adjective.
But besides the irony he still uses direct language to show his opinion, for example in Cobblers (l. 23).
In the next paragraph one can see an enumeration.

By calling all important states results of trade, prosperity, cultural exports, diplomacy and national security (ll. 26f.), Thethe author makes this problem of language knowledge seem like an essential states matter and an almost globalized concern.

Through his mentioning statistiksstatistics which show the decrease of school qualifications in foreign languages (cf. ll. 13-17) and the need of language skills in business (cf. ll. 28-32) he even strengthens those effects and underlines his argumentation with numbers, which make it more credible.

Worne summarizes these statistiksstatistics by explaining that for a company it is much more efficient to have a worker being able to use foreign language instead of having a worker and needing a translator (cf. ll. 40-43).
He uses this example to underline the problem of companies hiring abroad, mentioned before (cf. ll. 32-35).

In his appeal to the parents of the UK (and I'm one) (l. 46), besides including himself again, he explains that schools can only offer to educate in language (cf. l. 51) but it is the job of the parents to shift the view on language in the households (cf. ll. 46-49) and make more students use these oportunitiesopportunities.

In his comment John Worne uses a special combination of irony, inclusive language and serious argumentation which makes him on the one hand seem to be harsh and strict while on the other hand it also softs his treatment and makes him seem sympathetic to the reader.
